Award.AwardTitle: Early Career: Acquisition of a Raman Spectrometer for a Mineral Physics research laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports the acquisition of a Raman spectrometer dedicated to the analysis of vibrational properties of Earth Materials. It will be used to investigate the properties of hydrous minerals, melts, and fluids at high pressures and temperatures relevant for subduction zone conditions.

The Raman spectrometer will be housed in the Earth Materials Laboratory, Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences at Florida State University. The instrument will benefit students by facilitating their training in vibrational spectroscopic methods as applied to high-pressure mineral physics research. It will therefore support future scientific workforce needs. The Raman spectrometer will also be open to use by faculty members and researchers across other departments at FSU as well as visiting scientists from other universities. The instrument will also be used for local K-12 outreach. The expected benefits are closely aligned with NSF's mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national welfare through student training in analytical techniques in geoscience, mineral physics, and soild-state physics & chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to establish a Raman Spectroscopic facility in the Earth Materials /Mineral Physics laboratory at the department of Earth Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences, Florida State University. Since PI received the grant in July 2017, the Raman Spectrometer has been acquired from Horiba. A separate research grade optical table hosts the Raman instrument. At this moment, the instrument is fully functional and PI and his group have been setting up the high pressure diamond anvil lab and collecting preliminary data.

The Raman spectrometer has been extensively used to address several scientific questions relevant to Earth and Palnetary Sciences including but not limited to- behvior of hydrous minerals at pressures and temperature conditions relevant for subduction zone settings; behavior of framework silicates relevant for crustal conditions; and long chain organic molecules at extreme conditions. In future it is anticipated that scientific questions related to the understanding of the behavior of aqueous fluids/melts at conditions relevant to Earth's interior will be expored. In addition, the instruement is also useful to faculty members and researchers from departments across FSU. The instrument has already been used to examine metal organic framework and it is anticipated that the instrument will be used to explore the behavior of MOF and novel materials in near future.  

Several under/graduate students and post-doctoral scholars have used this instrumentation to explore and adress their specific scientific questions. It is anticipated that the Raman spectrometer will be a key instrumentation for the members of the Earth Materials group for years to come.
